#Text=Douglas ( Isle of Man )
#Text=Douglas ( in Manx : Doolish ) is the capital city of the Isle of Man , a crown dependency of the United Kingdom in the Irish Sea .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Douglas is the capital of the Isle of Man .
#Text=The island 's government assembly , the House of Keys , meets there .
#Text=Douglas is also the main centre of commerce on the island and home to around a quarter of the island 's population .
#Text=The town 's main areas are the sea front which stretches for 2 miles between the Onchan and the Sea Terminal .
#Text=The Quay area near the Sea Terminal is popular for drinking and shopping .
#Text=Away from the sea front are shopping districts , financial offices and government buildings while Upper Douglas becomes more residential .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The only operating commercial airport on the Island is the ( IOM ) in Ronaldsway , located about 15km south of Douglas .
#Text=Flights depart to London Luton , Gatwick and City , as well as ( amongst other destinations ) Dublin , Manchester , Leeds , Bradford and Birmingham .
#Text=Select flights to smaller UK airports often operate during the summer months .
#Text=By car
#Text=If you are flying into Ronaldway Airport , then you can rent a car to drive into the town .
#Text=By boat
#Text=Isle of Man Steam Packet Co Ferries from Liverpool / Birkenhead and Heysham in England to Douglas operate all year round .
#Text=Ferries from Belfast and Dublin operate a more restricted schedule to Douglas .
#Text=Transport to the island during the last week of May and the first week of June may be extremely expensive and often fully booked a year in advance because of the TT Festival .
#Text=By steam train
#Text=Close to the airport is a halt stop of the Isle of Man Steam Railway which runs from Port Erin , in the south , to Douglas .
#Text=It offers one of the few opportunities to take a steam train from the airport to your destination .
#Text=Trains run during the summer months only .
#Text=Get around
#Text=A horsedrawn tram , one of only two left in the world , runs the Douglas promenade 's length , from the ferry terminal to the Manx Electric Railway 's southern terminal .
#Text=There is also a bus service in town .
#Text=Douglas is easily walkable .
#Text=See
#Text=Manx Museum , Kingswood Grove , Douglas , IM1 3LY , ☏ +441624648000 .
#Text=Museum dedicated to the history and the natural history of the Isle of Man .
#Text=There is a section dedicated to Viking finds .
#Text=Free entry .
#Text=Castle Mona .
#Text=A seaside mansion designed by George Steuart for John Murray , 4th Duke of Atholl .
#Text=Completed in 1804 .
#Text=Jubilee clock .
#Text=A street clock commemorating the Golden Jubilee of Queen Victoria 's reign ( 1887 ) .
#Text=Gaiety Theatre , Harris Promenade ( Buses 1 , 2 , 11 , 12 , 12A , 13 , 13A , 13B , 13C and 13D stop at the Gaiety Theatre ) , ☏ +441624600555 .
#Text=1900 theatre and one of the few remaining theatres designed by Frank Matcham .
#Text=Incredibly detailed interior
#Text=Do
#Text=Buy Kippers .
#Text=Buy kippers from one of the two kipper shops on Strand Street
#Text=Go on the Horse Tram Railway .
#Text=Travel from the Sea Terminal to the far end of Douglas Bay using the Horse Tram £3 ( Aug 08 )
#Text=apx .
#Text=Isle of Man TT ( Tourist Trophy ) , Grandstand , IM2 6DA .
#Text=This is one of the world 's best-known motorcycle road races .
#Text=See the start of the TT from the grandstand overlooking Nobles Park .
#Text=Tynwald ( Parliament ) .
#Text=Mon 2PM or Fri 10AM .
#Text=Tour the home of Tynwald , which is claimed to be the oldest parliament in the world , dating back to 979 .
#Text=free .
#Text=Buy
#Text=Douglas is the island 's shopping capital and most chain stores are located in Strand Street and Duke Street close to the sea front .
#Text=Smaller independent shops can be found around the Quay area close to Strand Street and the Sea Terminal ( where ferries from the UK and Ireland dock ) .
#Text=This area has been semi-pedestrianised in recent years and includes small cafés , pubs and Douglas Train Station ( for steam trains to the south of the island ) .
#Text=Eat
#Text=The Isle of Man prides itself on the quality and variety of its locally produced food and drink – from freshly caught seafood , to succulent meat and specially brewed beers and spirits .
#Text=A visit to the island really is the perfect opportunity to see what the local producers , farmers and fishermen do best .

#Text=If you ’re a fan of seafood try traditional Manx Kippers which are herring fillets that have been smoked over hot oak chips , or Manx Queen Scallops - Queenies as they are more commonly known - which are sustainably sourced from Manx waters .

#Text=If you prefer meat you ’ll find a large selection to choose from including the rich and tasty Loaghtan Lamb - which comes from an unusual horned sheep which is believed to have been brought to the island by the Vikings .
#Text=And for those visitors with a sweet tooth , make sure you do n’t miss out on creamy Manx ice cream , handmade confectionary and traditional cakes including the Manx Bonnag .
#Text=One favourite , of tourists and residents alike , is Davison 's Ice Cream on Douglas Promenade .
#Text=You ’ll be able to sample this produce at the regular farmers ’ markets , supermarkets and a variety of cafes , pubs and restaurants around the island .
#Text=Food in the Isle of Man is more expensive than in the UK .
#Text=Expect to pay upwards of £30 per head for a meal in a restaurant .
#Text=Tanroagan , 9 Ridgeway St , IM1 1EW , ☏ +441624612355 , ✉ fish@tanroagan.co.uk .
#Text=M - F 11:30AM – 3PM , M - Sa 6PM – 9:30PM .
#Text=A seafood restaurant : various fish , scallops , lobsters , etc. Good selection of wine .
#Text=14 North Restaurant , 14 N Quay , ☏ +441624664414 .
#Text=Drink
#Text=There are many places to drink in Douglas , from typical British pubs to cocktail and wine bars .
#Text=The Rovers Return , 11 Church St , IM1 2AG , ☏ +441624611101 .
#Text=noon-midnight .
#Text=A fire station-themed pub , apparently one of the oldest in Douglas .
#Text=Sleep
#Text=There are a large number of bed and breakfasts in Douglas with high quality hotels such as the Sefton and Hilton also available ( £90 a night ) .
#Text=It is strongly that you book ahead especially in the TT Season when rooms will be at a premium .
